title: What Should an OMS Actually Do?
excerpt: Shopping baskets, not PNRs. Ann Cederhall clarifies what to look for when evaluating Order Management Systems for airline retail.
author: Retailaer
content:
From our reading list: When Ann Cederhall explains what an OMS should actually do, she focuses on outcomes, not buzzwords. This post provides a clear evaluation framework for any airline assessing their technology options.

The Core Insight

While retailers can conduct business using any PSS, an OMS provides significant advantages by centering operations around shopping baskets rather than PNRs.

What Order-Based Systems Enable

  • Consolidate multiple PNRs and products in single baskets
  • Enable dynamic bundling and discounting across all items
  • Support flexible product addition/removal
  • Apply unified business rules across orders

Practical Use Cases

  • Seat passengers with different PNRs together on shared flight segments
  • Extend loyalty benefits to companions within the same order
  • Cross-sell ancillary products (hotels, insurance) with flight bundles

How to Evaluate OMS Solutions

Ann recommends assessing whether systems:

  • Integrate with existing infrastructure
  • Support shopping basket models
  • Enable dynamic discounting
  • Maintain PSS platform agnosticism

Bottom line: Select solutions that address your specific customer pain points. Modern OMS capabilities enable seamless omnichannel experiences and improved order processing.
